column1:
PASSKEY ONLINE/HOCK INTERNATIONAL PART 1 FORMS LIST (SEPTEMBER 2023)
(due dates for the forms can be found in your Passkey materials and/or in the IRS instructions for the forms.

column2: Form Description
column3: Form's Purpose

column2: Application for Enrollment to Practice Before the Internal Revenue Service
column3: Use to apply for the Enrolled Agent license upon successfully passing all three SEE exam parts.

column2: United States Estate (and Generation-Skipping Transfer) Tax Return
column3: The executor of a decedent's estate uses this to figure the estate tax imposed by Chapter 11 of the Internal Revenue Code. Form 706 is also used to compute the generation-skipping transfer (GST) tax imposed by Chapter 13 on direct skips.

column2: United States Gift (and Generation-Skipping Transfer) Tax Return
column3: Use to report transfers subject to the federal gift and certain generation-skipping transfer (GST) taxes AND allocation of the lifetime GST exemption to property transferred during the transferor's lifetime.

column2: Reduction of Tax Attributes Due to Discharge of Indebtedness (and Section 1082 Basis Adjustment)
column3: Use to determine, under certain circumstances described in section 108, the amount of discharged indebtedness that can be excluded from gross income.

column2: U.S. Individual Income Tax Return
column3: Used by U.S. taxpayers to file an annual income tax return.

column2: U.S. Nonresident Alien Income Tax Return
column3: An individual may need to use this if they are or were a nonresident alien engaged in a trade or business in the United States, represented a deceased person who would have had to file this form OR represented an estate or trust that had to file this form.

column2: Amended U.S. Individual Income Tax Return
column3: Use to correct Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-NR (or older filings of Form 1040-A, 1040-EZ, or 1040-NR-EZ); make certain elections after the deadline; change amounts previously adjusted by the IRS; make a claim for a carryback due to a loss or unused credit.

column2: U.S. Income Tax for Estates and Trusts
column3: The fiduciary of a domestic decedent's estate, trust, or bankruptcy estate uses this to report the income, deductions, gains, losses, etc. of the estate or trust; the income that is either accumulated or held for future distribution or distributed currently to the beneficiaries; any income tax liability of the estate or trust; employment taxes on wages paid to household employees.

column2: Annual Withholding Tax Return for U.S. Source Income of Foreign Persons
column3: Use to report the tax withheld under chapter 3 on certain income of foreign persons, including nonresident aliens, foreign partnerships, foreign corporations, foreign estates, and foreign trusts; the tax withheld under chapter 4 on withholdable payments; the tax withheld pursuant to section 5000C on specified federal procurement payments; payments that are reported on Form 1042-S under chapters 3 or 4.

column2: Foreign Person's U.S. Source Income Subject to Withholding
column3: Use to report income and amounts withheld as described in the instructions of this form; specified Federal procurement payments paid to foreign persons that are subject to withholding under section 5000C; distributions of effectively connected income by a publicly traded partnership or nominee.

column2: Annual Summary and Transmittal of Forms 1042-S
column3: Use to transmit paper Forms 1042-S to the IRS.

column2: Mortgage Interest Statement
column3: Use to report mortgage interest of $600 or more received during the year in the course of your trade or business from an individual, including a sole proprietor.                       NOTE: this form is NOT used for reporting mortgage payments received by an individual who is selling their personal residence and the buyer is making payments to the seller.

column2: Student Loan Interest Statement
column3: Use to report the amount of student loan interest paid by the recipient during the tax year.

column2: Tuition Statement
column3:
Eligible educational institutions use this for each student they enroll and for whom a reportable transaction is made.

Insurers file this form for each individual to whom they made reimbursements or refunds of qualified tuition and related expenses.

column2: Acquisition or Abandonment of Secured Property
column3:
Use for each borrower if you lend money in connection with your trade or business and, in full or partial satisfaction of the debt, you acquire an interest in property that is security for the debt, or you have reason to know that the property has been abandoned.

You need not be in the business of lending money to be subject to this reporting requirement.

column2: Proceeds from Broker and Barter Exchange Transactions
column3: A broker or barter exchange must use this form for each person: 1) For whom, they sold stocks, commodities, regulated futures contracts, foreign currency contracts, forward contracts, debt instruments, options, securities futures contracts, etc., for cash; 2) Who received cash, stock, or other property from a corporation that the broker knows or has reason to know has had its stock acquired in an acquisition of control or had a substantial change in capital structure reportable on Form 8806; or 3) Who exchanged property or services through a barter exchange.

column2: Cancellation of Debt
column3: Use to report each debtor for whom a $600 or more amount of debt is canceled. The issue MUST be an applicable financial entity AND an identifiable event has occurred.

column2: Dividends and Distributions
column3: Banks and other financial institutions use this to report dividends and other distributions to taxpayers and to the IRS.

column2: Certain Government Payments
column3: Federal, state, or local governments use this if they made payments of: 1) Unemployment compensation; 2) State or local income tax refunds, credits, or offsets; 3) Reemployment trade adjustment assistance (RTAA) payments; 4) Taxable grants; 5) Agricultural payments; or 6) They also file this form if they received payments on a Commodity Credit Corporation (CCC) loan.

column2: Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) Advance Payments
column3: Use if you received any advance payments during the calendar year of qualified health insurance payments for the benefit of eligible trade adjustment assistance (TAA), Reemployment TAA, or Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC) pension recipients and their qualifying family members.

column2: Interest Income
column3: Use for each person: 1) To whom you paid amounts reportable in boxes 1, 3, and 8 of at least $10; 2) For whom you withheld and paid any foreign tax on interest; or 3) From whom you withheld (and did not refund) any federal income tax under the backup withholding rules regardless of the amount of the payment.

column2: Payment Card and Third-Party Network Transactions
column3: Use to report payments received during the tax year credit/debit/gift cards, payment apps or online marketplaces. May be issued for any amounts received, but MUST be issued at this point if $20,000 or more is received. This amount is lowered to $600 or more beginning with tax year 2023.

column2: Long-Term Care and Accelerated Death Benefits
column3: Use if you pay any long-term care benefits, including accelerated death benefits. Payers include insurance companies, governmental units, and viatical settlement providers.

column2: Miscellaneous Income
column3: Use to report $10 or more of royalty or broker payments in lieu of dividends or tax exempt interest.                                                                                                                                                           ALSO used to report $600 or more in rental income, prizes and awards and much more. You can see the list of all uses of this form for the $600 or more required reporting at: https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-1099-misc (NOTE: some of the income reported on this form MAY be self-employment income, subject to self-employment taxes).

column2: Non-Employee Compensation
column3: Use to report payments to each person to whom a business has paid at least $600 for services performed by each person, including materials and parts, OR payments to an attorney.

column2: Original Issue Discount
column3: Use if the original issue discount (OID) includible in gross income is at least $10; For any person for whom you withheld and paid any foreign tax on OID; From whom you withheld (and did not refund) any federal income tax under the backup withholding rules even if the amount of the OID is less than $10.

column2: Taxable Distributions Received from Cooperatives
column3: Cooperatives use this for each person to whom the they paid at least $10 in patronage dividends and other distributions described in section 6044(b) AND from whom they withheld any federal income tax under the backup withholding rules regardless of the amount of the payment.

column2: Payments from Qualified Education Programs
column3: Use (info copy only) if you are an officer or an employee, or the designee of an officer or employee, having control of a program established by a state or eligible educational institution OR made a distribution from a qualified tuition program (QTP).

column2: Distributions from Pensions, Annuities, Retirement or Profit-Sharing Plans, IRAs, Insurance Contractors, and more
column3: Use to report a designated distribution or a payment treated as having been made as a distribution in the amount of $10 or more.

column2: Proceeds from Real Estate Transactions
column3: Use to report a sale or transaction that consists in whole or in part of the sale or exchange of money, indebtedness, property or services of any present or future ownership interest in improved or unimproved land, airspace, permanent structures and more.

column2: Distributions from an Health Savings Account (HAS), Archer Medical Savings Account (MSA) or Medicare Advantage MSA
column3: Use to report distributions made from an HSA), Archer MSA or MA MSA paid directly to a medical service provider or to the account holder. A separate return must be filed for each plan type.

column2: Foreign Tax Credit (Individual, Estate or Trust)
column3: Use to claim the foreign tax credit if the election, earlier, doesn't apply and: 1) You are an individual, estate, or trust; and 2) You paid or accrued certain foreign taxes to a foreign country or U.S. possession.

column2: Employee Business Expenses
column3: Employees file this to deduct ordinary and necessary expenses for their job. An ordinary expense is one that is common and accepted in your field of trade, business, or profession. A necessary expense is one that is helpful and appropriate for your business. An expense does not have to be required to be considered necessary

column2: Multiple Support Declaration
column3: Use to: 1) Identify each other eligible person who paid over 10% of the support of your qualifying relative whom you are claiming as a dependent; and 2) Indicate that you have a signed statement from each other eligible person waiving his or her right to claim that person as a dependent.

column2: Underpayment of Estimated Tax by Individuals, Estates and Trusts
column3: Use to see if the taxpayer(s) owe a penalty for underpaying your estimated tax. The IRS will generally figure your penalty for them and, if this is the case, do not file this form with the tax return. The taxpayer(s) can, however, use this to figure their penalty if they wish and include the penalty on their return. There are some situations in which the taxpayer(s) must file this, such as to request a waiver.

column2: Underpayment of Estimated Tax by Farmers and Fishermen
column3: Individuals, estates, and trusts with at least two-thirds of their gross annual income from farming or fishing use this form to see if they owe a penalty for underpaying their estimated tax.

column2: Child and Dependent Care Expenses
column3: If you paid someone to care for your child or other qualifying person so you (and your spouse if filing jointly) could work or look for work, you may be able to take the credit for child and dependent care expenses.

column2: Foreign Earned Income
column3: If you qualify, you can use to figure your foreign earned income exclusion and your housing exclusion or deduction. You cannot exclude or deduct more than your foreign earned income for the year.

column2: Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representative
column3: Use to authorize an individual to represent you before the IRS. The individual you authorize must be a person eligible to practice before the IRS.

column2: Annual Return to Report Transactions with Foreign Trusts and Receipt of Certain Foreign Gifts
column3: U.S. persons (and executors of estates of U.S. decedents) file this to report: 1) Certain transactions with foreign trusts; 2) Ownership of foreign trusts under the rules of sections Internal Revenue Code 671 through 679; and 3) Receipt of certain large gifts or bequests from certain foreign persons.

column2: Moving Expenses
column3: Use to figure your moving expense deduction for a move related to the start of work at a new principal place of work (workplace). If the new workplace is outside the United States or its possessions, you must be a U.S. citizen or resident alien to deduct your expenses.

column2: Application for Exemption from Social Security and Medicare Taxes and Waiver of Benefits
column3: Members of recognized religious groups file this to apply for exemption from Social Security and Medicare taxes.

column2: Social Security and Medicare Tax on Unreported Tip Income
column3: Use only to figure the social security and Medicare tax owed on tips you did not report to your employer, including any allocated tips shown on your Form(s) W-2 that you must report as income.

column2: Request for Transcript of Tax Return
column3: Use to request any of the transcripts: tax return, tax account, wage and income, record of account and verification of non-filling.

column2: Depreciation and Amortization (Including Information on Listed Property)
column3: Except as otherwise noted, complete and file this if you are claiming any of the following: 1) Depreciation for property placed in service during the 2022 tax year; 2) A Section 179 expense deduction (which may include a carryover from a previous year); 3) Depreciation on any vehicle or other listed property (regardless of when it was placed in service); 4) A deduction for any vehicle reported on a form other than Schedule C (Form 1040), Profit or Loss From Business; 5) Any depreciation on a corporate income tax return (other than Form 1120-S); or 6) Amortization of costs that begins during the 2022 tax year.

column2: Casualties and Thefts
column3: Attach to a taxpayer's tax return to report gains and losses from casualties and thefts.

column2: Sales of Business Property
column3:
Use to report:
The sale or exchange of property.
The involuntary conversion of property and capital assets.
The disposition of noncapital assets. 
The disposition of capital assets not reported on Schedule D.
The gain or loss for partners and S corporation shareholders from certain section 179 property dispositions by
partnerships and S corporations.
The computation of recapture amounts under sections 179 and 280F(b)(2) when the business use of section 179 or listed property decreases to 50% or less.
Gains or losses treated as ordinary gains or losses, if you are a trader in securities or commodities and made a mark-to-market election under Internal Revenue Code section 475(f).

column2: Substitute for Form W-2, Wage and Tax Statement, or Form 1099-R, Distributions from Pensions, Annuities, Retirement or Profit-Sharing Plans, IRAs, Insurance Contracts, Etc.
column3:
Serves as a substitute for Form W-2, Form W-2c, and Form 1099-R (original or corrected), and is completed by taxpayers or their representatives when:
Their employer or payer does not give them a Form W-2 or Form 1099-R.
An employer or payer has issued an incorrect Form W-2 or Form 1099-R.

column2: Application for Automatic Extension of Time to File U.S. Individual Income Tax Return
column3: To apply for a 6-month extension to file an individual income tax return. NOTE: This does not extend the time to pay any income tax debt due for the extended return.

column2: Additional Taxes on Qualified Plans (including IRAs) and Other Tax-Favored Accounts
column3: Use to report additional taxes on IRAs, other qualified retirement plans, modified endowment contracts, Coverdell ESAs, QTPs, Archer MSAs, or HSAs.

column2: Repayment of the First-Time Homebuyer Credit
column3: Use this form to notify the IRS that the home for which you claimed the credit was disposed of or ceased to be your main home AND to figure the amount of the credit you must repay with your tax return.

column2: Information Return of U.S. Persons with Respect to Certain Foreign Corporations
column3: Certain U.S. citizens and residents who are officers, directors, or shareholders in certain foreign corporations filethis  and schedules to satisfy the reporting requirements of sections 6038 and 6046, and the related regulations.

column2: IRA Contribution Information (Info Copy Only)
column3: File this form for each person for whom you maintained any individual retirement arrangement (IRA), including a deemed IRA under section 408(q).

column2: ABLE Account Contribution Information
column3: Any state or its agency or instrumentality that establishes and maintains a qualified ABLE program must file this form with the IRS, for each ABLE account.

column2: Health Savings Account (HAS), Archer Medical Savings Account (MSA) or Medicare Advantage MSA Information
column3: File this form for each person for whom you maintained an HSA, Archer MSA or MA MSA during the year. A separate form is required for each type of plan.

column2: Residential Energy Credits
column3: Use to figure and take your residential energy credits. The residential energy credits are: 1) the nonbusiness energy property credit; and 2) the residential energy efficient property credit.

column2: Alternative Minimum Tax - Individuals
column3: Use to figure the amount, if any, of your alternative minimum tax (AMT). The AMT applies to taxpayers who have certain types of income that receive favorable treatment, or who qualify for certain deductions, under the tax law. These tax benefits can significantly reduce the regular tax of some taxpayers with higher economic incomes. The AMT sets a limit on the amount these benefits can be used to reduce total tax.

column2: Installment Sale Income
column3: Use to report income from an installment sale on the installment method. Generally, an installment sale is a disposition of property where at least one payment is received after the end of the tax year in which the disposition occurs.

column2: Application for Automatic Extension of Time to File Certain Business Income Tax, Information and Other Returns
column3: Use to request an automatic 6-month extension of time to file certain business income tax, information, and other returns

column2: Disclosure Statement
column3: Taxpayers and tax return preparers use this form to disclose items or positions that are not otherwise adequately disclosed on a tax return to avoid certain penalties.

column2: Regulation Disclosure Statement
column3: Taxpayers and tax return preparers use this form to disclose positions taken on a tax return that are contrary to Treasury regulations.

column2: Non-Cash Charitable Contributions
column3: Individuals, partnerships and corporations use this form to report information about non-cash charitable contributions when the amount of their deduction for all non-cash gifts is more than $500.

column2: Release/Revocation of Release of Claim to Exemption for Child by Custodial Parent
column3: If you are the custodial parent, you can use Form 8332 to do the following: 1) Release a claim to exemption for your child so that the noncustodial parent can claim an exemption for the child; or 2) Revoke a previous release of claim to exemption for your child.

column2: Injured Spouse Allocation
column3: The injured spouse on a jointly filed tax return uses this to get back their share of the joint refund when the joint overpayment is applied to a past-due obligation of the other spouse.

column2: U.S. Individual Income Tax Transmittal for an IRS e-File Return
column3: Taxpayers and Electronic Return Originators (EROs) use this form to send any required paper forms or supporting documentation listed next to the checkboxes on the front of the form. Use this form solely to transmit the forms listed on the front of the form.

column2: Passive Activity Loss Limitations
column3: Noncorporate taxpayers use this to: 1) Figure the amount of any passive activity loss (PAL) for the current tax year; or 2) Report the application of prior year unallowed PALs.

column2: Non-Deductible IRAs
column3:
Use to report:
Nondeductible contributions you made to traditional IRAs.
Distributions from traditional, SEP, or SIMPLE IRAs, if you have ever made nondeductible contributions to traditional IRAs.
Conversions from traditional, SEP, or SIMPLE IRAs to Roth IRAs.
Distributions from Roth IRAs.

column2: Credit for Prior Year Minimum Tax - Individuals, Estates and Trusts
column3: Individuals, estates, and trusts use this form to figure: 1) the minimum tax credit, if any, for alternative minimum tax (AMT) they incurred in prior tax years; or 2) any credit carryforward to next year.

column2: Exclusion of Interest From Series EE and I U.S. Savings Bonds Issued After 1989
column3: If a person cashed series EE or I U.S. savings bonds this year that were issued after 1989, the person may be able to exclude from their income part or all of the interest on those bonds. Use this form to figure the amount of any interest you may exclude.

column2: Tax Information Authorization
column3: Use to: 1) authorize any individual, corporation, firm, organization, or partnership you designate to inspect and/or receive your confidential information verbally or in writing for the type of tax and the years or periods listed on the form; or 2) delete or revoke prior tax information authorizations.

column2: Change of Address
column3: Use to notify the Internal Revenue Service of a change to your home mailing address.

column2: Expenses for Business Use of Your Home
column3: Use to figure the allowable expenses for business use of your home on Schedule C (Form 1040) and any carryover to 2023 of amounts not deductible in 2022.

column2: Request for Innocent Spouse Relief
column3: Taxpayers use this to request relief from tax liability, plus related penalties and interest, when they believe only their spouse or former spouse should be held responsible for all or part of the tax.

column2: Information to Claim Certain Credits After Disallowance
column3: Taxpayers complete this and attach it to their tax return if: 1) their earned income credit (EIC), child tax credit (CTC)/additional child tax credit (ACTC), credit for other dependents (ODC) or American opportunity credit (AOTC) was reduced or disallowed for any reason other than a math or clerical error; or 2) they want to take the credit(s) and meet all the requirements.

column2: Education Credits (American Opportunity and Lifetime Learning Credits)
column3: Use to figure and claim your education credits, which are based on qualified education expenses paid to an eligible postsecondary educational institution. There are two education credits: the American Opportunity Credit, part of which may be refundable AND the Lifetime Learning Credit, which is nonrefundable.

column2: Return of U.S. Persons With Respect to Certain Foreign Partnerships
column3:
A U.S. person uses this to report the information required under:
Section 6038 (reporting with respect to controlled foreign partnerships).
Section 6038B (reporting of transfers to foreign partnerships).
Section 6046A (reporting of acquisitions, dispositions, and changes in foreign partnership interests).

column2: IRS e-File Signature Authorization
column3: This is the declaration document and signature authorization for an e-filed return filed by an electronic return originator (ERO). Complete this form when: 1) the Practitioner PIN method is used; and/or 2) the taxpayer authorizes the ERO to enter or generate the taxpayer’s personal identification number (PIN) on his or her e-filed individual income tax return.

column2: Credit for Qualified Retirement Savings Contributions
column3: Use to figure the amount, if any, of your retirement savings contributions credit (also known as the saver’s credit)

column2: Allocation of Refund (Including Savings Bond Purchases)
column3: Use to directly deposit your refund (or part of it) to one or more accounts at a bank or other financial institution (such as a mutual fund, brokerage firm, or credit union) in the United States. This form can also be used to buy up to $5,000 in paper series I savings bonds with your refund.

column2: Health Savings Accounts (HSAs)
column3:
File this to: 1) report health savings account (HSA) contributions (including those made on your behalf and employer contributions); 2) figure your HSA deduction; and 3) report distributions from HSAs.
Figure amounts you must include in income and additional tax you may owe if you fail to be an eligible individual.

column2: Uncollected Social Security and Medicare Tax on Wages
column3: Use to figure and report your share of the uncollected social security and Medicare taxes due on your compensation if you were an employee but were treated as an independent contractor by your employer.

column2: Statement of Specified Foreign Financial Assets
column3: Use to report your specified foreign financial assets if the total value of all the specified foreign financial assets in which you have an interest is more than the appropriate reporting threshold.

column2: Preparer Explanation for Not Filing Electronically
column3: Specified tax return preparers use this form to explain why a particular return is being filed on paper.

column2: Sales and Other Dispositions of Capital Assets
column3: Use to reconcile amounts that were reported to you and the IRS on Form 1099-B or 1099-S (or substitute statement) with the amounts you report on your return. The subtotals from this form will then be  carried over to Schedule D (Form 1040), where gain or loss will be calculated in aggregate.

column2: Report of foreign bank and financial accounts.
column3: A U.S. person, including a citizen, resident, corporation, partnership, limited liability company, trust and estate, must file an FBAR to report a financial interest in or signature or other authority over at least one financial account located outside the United States if the aggregate value of those foreign financial accounts exceeded $10,000 at any time during the calendar year.

column2: Railroad retirement benefits.
column3: This is a two-part form. Railroad retirement benefits (Social Security equivalent) are reported on RRB-1099, the blue form (Tier 1). Tier one reports the Social Security equivalent amounts. These amounts DO NOT include Medicare premiums deducted from the taxpayer's Social Security benefits during the tax year. The RRB-1099-R, the green form (Tier 2), contains the taxpayer's PII and non-Social Security equivalent benefit payments administered by the RRB.

column2: Additional Income and Adjustments to Income
column3: Use if you have additional income, such as business or farm income or loss, unemployment compensation, or prize or award money OR you have any adjustments to income, such as student loan interest, self-employment tax, or educator expenses.

column2: Additional Taxes
column3: Use if you owe alternative minimum tax (AMT) or need to make an excess advance premium tax credit repayment OR you owe other taxes, such as self-employment tax, household employment taxes, additional tax on IRAs or other qualified retirement plans and tax favored accounts.

column2: Additional Credits and Payments
column3: Use if you can claim a nonrefundable credit (other than the child tax credit or the credit for other dependents), such as the foreign tax credit, education credits, or general business credit OR you can claim a refundable credit (other than the earned income credit, American opportunity credit, or additional child tax credit), such as the net premium tax credit or qualied sick and family leave credits from Schedule H OR you have other payments, such as an amount paid with a request for an extension to file or excess social security tax withheld.

column2: Credits for Qualifying Children and Other Dependents
column3: Use to figure your child tax credits, to report advance child tax credit payments you received in 2021, and to figure any additional tax owed if you received excess advance child tax credit payments during 2021.

column2: Itemized Deductions
column3: Use to figure your itemized deductions. In most cases, your federal income tax will be less if you take the larger of your itemized deductions or your standard deduction.

column2: Interest and Ordinary Dividends
column3: Use if any of the following apply: you had over $1,500 of taxable interest or ordinary dividends; you received interest from a seller-financed mortgage and the buyer used the property as a personal residence; you have accrued interest from a bond; you are reporting original issue discount (OID) in an amount less than the amount shown on Form 1099-OID; you are reducing your interest income on a bond by the amount of amortizable bond premium; you are claiming the exclusion of interest from series EE or I U.S. savings bonds issued after 1989; you received interest or ordinary dividends as a nominee; you had a financial interest in, or signature authority over, a financial account in a foreign country or you received a distribution from, or were a grantor of, or transferor to, a foreign trust. Part III of the schedule has questions about foreign accounts and trusts.

column2: Profit or Loss from Business (Sole Proprietorship)
column3: Use to report income or loss from a business you operated or a profession you practiced as a sole proprietor. An activity qualifies as a business if: your primary purpose for engaging in the activity is for income or profit; you are involved in the activity with continuity and regularity.

column2: Capital Gains and Losses
column3: Use to report the following: the sale or exchange of a capital asset not reported on another form or schedule; gains from involuntary conversions (other than from casualty or theft) of capital assets not held for business or profit; capital gain distributions not reported directly on Form 1040 (or effectively connected capital gain distributions not reported directly on Form 1040-NR); non-business bad debts.

column2: Supplemental Income and Loss
column3: Use to report income or loss from rental real estate, royalties, partnerships, S corporations, estates, trusts, and residual interests in real estate mortgage investment conduits (REMICs).

column2: Earned Income Credit
column3: After you have figured your earned income credit (EIC), use Schedule EIC (Form 1040 or 1040-SR) to give the IRS information about your qualifying child(ren).

column2: Profit or Loss From Farming
column3: Use to report farm income and expenses.

column2: Household Employment Taxes
column3: Use to report household employment taxes if you paid cash wages to a household employee and the wages were subject to social security, Medicare, or FUTA taxes, or if you withheld federal income tax.

column2: Income Averaging for Farmers and Fishermen
column3: Use to elect to figure your income tax by averaging, over the previous 3 years (base years), all or part of your taxable income from your trade or business of farming or fishing. This election may give you a lower tax if your income from farming or fishing last year is high and your taxable income for one or more of the 3 prior years was low.

column2: Beneficiary Filing Form 1040 or 1040-SR
column3: Use to report a beneficiary's share of the estate’s or trust’s income, credits, deductions, etc., on your Form 1040 or 1040-SR. Keep it for your records. Don’t file it with your tax return, unless backup withholding was reported in box 13, code B.

column2: Partner’s Share of Income, Deductions, Credits, etc.
column3: Use to report your share of the partnership's income, deductions, credits, etc. Keep it for your records. Don’t file it with your tax return unless you are specifically required to do so. (See the instructions for Code O. Backup withholding, later.) The partnership files a copy of Schedule K-1 (Form 1065) with the IRS. The amount of loss and deduction you may claim on your tax return may be less than the amount reported on Schedule K-1. It is the partner's responsibility to consider and apply any applicable limitations.

column2: Shareholder's Share of Income, Deductions, Credits, etc. (For Shareholder's Use Only)
column3: Use to report your share of the corporation's income, deductions, credits, and other items. Keep it for your records. Don't file it with your tax return unless backup withholding is reported in box 13 using code O.

column2: Partners’ Distributive Share Items — International
column3: Used to report items of international tax relevance from the operation of a partnership.

column2: Shareholders’ Pro Rata Share Items — International
column3: Used to report items of international tax relevance from the operation of an S corporation.

column2: Partners’ Distributive Share Items — International
column3: Used to report items of international tax relevance from the operation of a partnership.

column2: Partner’s Share of Income, Deductions, Credits, etc. — International
column3: Generally used to report the share of the items reported on Schedule K-2. The information reported on Schedule K-3 is used to report information on a partner’s tax or information returns.

column2: Shareholder's Share of Income, Deductions, Credits, etc. — International
column3: Generally used to report to shareholders their share of the items reported on Schedule K-2. Shareholders must include the information reported on Schedule K-3 on their tax or information returns.

column2: Partner’s Share of Income, Deductions, Credits, etc. — International
column3: Generally used to report the share of the items reported on Schedule K-2. The information reported on Schedule K-3 is used to report information on a partner’s tax or information returns.

column2: Credit for the Elderly or Disabled
column3: Use to figure the credit for the elderly or disabled.

column2: Self-Employment Tax
column3: Use to figure the tax due on net earnings from self-employment. Social Security uses the information from this form to figure your benefits under the social security program.

column2: Foreign Person's US Source Income Subject to Withholding
column3: Use to report specified Federal procurement payments (e.g., Social Security benefits) paid to foreign persons subject to withholding under Section 5000C.

column2: Social Security benefits.
column3: This form is used by the Social Security Adminstration to report the total amount of Social Security benefits you received in the previous year.

column2: Wage and Tax Statement
column3: Every employer engaged in a trade or business who pays remuneration, including non-cash payments of $600 or more for the year (all amounts if any income, social security or Medicare tax was withheld) for services performed by an employee must file a Form W-2 for each employee (even if the employee is related to the employer) from whom: 1) income, Social Security or Medicare tax was withheld; 2) income tax would have been withheld if the employee had claimed no more than one withholding allowance or had not claimed exemption from withholding on Form W-4, Employee's Withholding Allowance Certificate.

column2: the
Cetain Gambling Winnings
column3: Use to report gambling winnings and any Federal tax withheld on those winnings. The requirements for reporting and withholding depend on: 1) the type of gambling; 2) the amount of the gambling winnings; and, 3) generally the ratio of the winnings to the wager.

column2: Employee's Withholding Certificate
column3: Use so that an employer can withhold the correct Federal income tax from their employee's pay. A new Form W-4 may be completed each year and when the employee's personal or financial situation changes.

column2: Application for IRS Individual Taxpayer Identification Number
column3: Use to apply for an IRS individual taxpayer identification number (ITIN). Also used to renew an existing ITIN that is expiring or that has already expired. Use this form, not Form W-7A for a child who is not a U.S. citizen or resident alien.

column2: Application for Taxpayer Identification Number for Pending U.S. Adoptions
column3: Use to apply for an IRS adoption taxpayer identification number (ATIN) for a child who is placed in your home for purposes of legal adoption. Taxpayers may not use this form if they are able to obtain a Social Security number for the child in time to file their tax return.
